headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: CD Yields Move Lower; 6-Month 'Jumbo' Slips to 0.25%
summary: Yields on certificates of deposit were mostly lower in the latest week.

summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for Sept. 27, 2011

headline: Treasury to Sell $30 Billion in Securities
summary: The Treasury plans to sell $30 billion Tuesday in four-week bills.

headline: CRS Report on Solyndra
summary: Before now-bankrupt Solyndra received a $535 million government loan, there were red flags. See a Congressional Research Service report about the solar-panel maker.

headline: Floods in India
summary: Monsoon rains have caused floods in Uttar Pradesh, Bihar and Orissa, leaving dozens dead and thousands displaced. Some snapshots.

headline: Two Subway Trains Crash in Shanghai
summary: About 260 people were injured when a subway train crashed into the rear end of another train at Yuyuan Garden station in Shanghai.

headline: Renren Buys Video-Sharing Site
summary: Social-networking company Renren agreed to acquire one of China's earliest video-sharing websites, 56.com, to combat competition from other Web companies.

headline: Deals India: Morning News Roundup
summary: News roundup from Indian newspapers, news wires and Web sites on Wednesday, September 28, 2011. Deals India has not verified the stories from other media organizations and does not vouch for their accuracy.

headline: Allstate Looks to Jettison Weak Agents
summary: Allstate pushed for growth eight years ago by bringing on hundreds of new agents. Now the insurer is seeking to boost results by encouraging many of them to go.

headline: WGC: India Gold Demand to Spurt
summary: India's brisk demand for gold during the first half of 2011 is likely to strengthen further in the second half despite price volatility, a World Gold Council executive said.

headline: Asia in Pictures
summary: Flood-affected farmers dry chili crops in Pakistan, subway travellers are rescued after a train collision in Shanghai, water buffalo races cap a festival in Cambodia and more.

headline: Sweeter Deal
summary: But earlier this month, Sify's board extended the due date by two years. Sify's vice president of finance, K.V. Kasturi, says the money is intended for future capital projects and will be collected when needed. Not that it should be difficult for Mr. Vesegna to find the cash. With shares trading at $4.54, he's sitting on a paper gain of nearly $500 million.

headline: Commodities Rebound
summary: Copper, silver and crude oil gained as growth-sensitive assets drew support from reports that European leaders would take steps to stabilize the financial system.

headline: Moody's Downgrades Kodak
summary: Moody's Investors Service dropped Kodak's credit ratings deeper into junk territory, warning that the company's decision to draw on its credit line signals weaker cash flow ahead.

headline: That CMBS Recovery? It's Faltering
summary: The recovery in the commercial mortgage-backed securities market has hit a rocky patch as investors demand increased protection and more-favorable terms for the riskiest portions of deals.

headline: Q&A With Canada's Prime Minister
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Stephen Harper spoke to The Wall Street Journal during his now-annual trip to the country's Far North, including stops in its arctic territories.

headline: Rally Loses Steam
summary: A sharp afternoon downdraft prompted U.S. stocks to erase more than half of their earlier gains.

headline: Protesting American Capitalism
summary: Protesters complaining about the power of the financial industry staged noisy demonstrations and slowed pedestrian traffic near Wall Street for a second week.

headline: CFTC Again Tarries on Position Limits
summary: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission has postponed for a second time a vote on new limits to speculation in commodity markets, delaying it until at least Oct. 18.

headline: The Cain Mutiny
summary: The pundits busy divining the reasons Herman Cain won that Florida straw poll so handily can't be blamed—it was a compelling spectacle and a distinctly satisfying one as straw poll results go.

headline: Crude Jumps 5%
summary: Oil futures posted their biggest one-day gain in more than four months on optimism that euro-zone leaders could craft a solution to region's sovereign debt crisis.

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: Dorothy Rabinowitz on the appeal of Herman Cain.

headline: Coast Guard, Transocean Look Into Gulf Oil Sheen
summary: The U.S. Coast Guard said it is working with Transocean to find out whether last year's wreckage of the Deepwater Horizon rig is the source of oil sheens that have appeared in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Venezuela Again Rejects Oil Settlement Talks
summary: Venezuela Tuesday rejected talk that his government was planning to settle with companies like Exxon Mobil and ConocoPhillips outside of official arbitration proceedings.

headline: Apple Sets iPhone Event Oct. 4
summary: Apple invited reporters to an iPhone-related event Oct. 4, setting the stage for the widely anticipated launch of its latest smartphone.

headline: Photos of the Day: Sept. 27
summary: In today's pictures, water buffalo races cap a festival in Cambodia, subway riders are rescued from a collision in Shanghai, protesters clash with police in Athens and more.

headline: Lomborg and Piot: Rethinking the Fight Against AIDS
summary: With funding down, it is critical to identify those measures thatachieve the most results for the money spent.

headline: Australia Military to Lift Curbs for Women
summary: Australia's military plans to lift all curbs on women in combat roles within five years, in a historic move that could see female commandos engaged in front-line operations in Afghanistan and intervening in other global conflicts.

headline: Gold, Silver Glitter
summary: Gold prices settled higher while silver soared as the recent selloff in the metals helped draw buyers back to the market.

headline: BASF to Sell Fertilizer Assets
summary: BASF said it will sell some of its fertilizer operations to Russia's EuroChem for $947.2 million, continuing the German chemical company's move away from commodities.

headline: Silver Displays Its Devilish Side Again
summary: Silver prices rebounded Tuesday after last week's huge slide, but some analysts say the volatile metal could face further difficulties.

headline: EU Raids Natural-Gas Companies in Antitrust Probe
summary: The EU's antitrust authority raided natural-gas companies in central and eastern Europe on suspicions that they might have breached the EU competition rules or would have information about such breaches.

headline: Copper Gains Further
summary: Copper futures settled higher on hopes that Europe will stabilize.

headline: EU To Seek Overhaul Of Audit Rules
summary: The European Union is set to propose an overhaul of its audit rules aimed at ending cozy relationships between auditors and their clients and injecting competition into a market now dominated by the Big Four auditing firms.

headline: For Strapped Cities, a 'New Normal'
summary: U.S. cities could remain in bad financial shape for a while, as a weak economy lowers property-tax and sales-tax revenue and city managers cope by freezing hiring, laying off workers and delaying infrastructure projects.

headline: Boeing's First Dreamliner in Photos
summary: All Nippon Airways took delivery Sunday of the first 787 Dreamliner, and flew the plane to Tokyo Tuesday. The twin-aisle, long-range jet is Boeing's first all-new plane since the 777 in 1995.

headline: N.Y. Fed Study Suggests Swaps Overhauls Need to Be Nuanced
summary: Trading in the off-exchange credit-derivatives market is less active than most liquid financial markets such as futures, according to a report by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, suggesting that dealers play a pivotal role in juicing flows and that rules governing the market should be tailored accordingly.

headline: VW Building New Passat in China
summary: Volkswagen plans to produce a version of its new Passat sedan in China as part of its comprehensive plant to ramp up local production there and broaden its product portfolio.

headline: Philippine Airlines Cancels Flights
summary: Philippine Airlines suspended all its early flights after some of its workers walked out of their jobs to protest the flag carrier's plan to outsource airport services, catering and call-center operations.

headline: Denmark Pushes Consolidation for Struggling Banks
summary: As funding costs surge and macro-economic gloom deepens over Denmark's highly fragmented banking sector, lawmakers and regulators are hoping that new measures to support the sector will help to bring about consolidation and prevent costly future collapses.

headline: House Leaders to Seek Funding OK
summary: House Republican leaders on Thursday will seek unanimous approval to continue current federal government funding levels for four days, just enough time to allow House lawmakers to return to Washington next week to take up the ongoing budget battle.

headline: Europe's Markets Rise
summary: European stocks surged, with oil and gold prices also firmly on the front foot, as the prospect of a beefed-up euro-zone bailout facility underpinned sentiment.

headline: Rio Tinto Raises Stake in Mongolia Project
summary: Rio Tinto raised its stake in Canada's Ivanhoe Mines to the maximum 49% as tensions continued over the massive Oyu Tolgoi copper-gold deposit in Mongolia.

headline: Flotek Industries, Crescent Financial: Biggest Price Gainers (FTK, CRFN)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Gainers.

headline: China's Offshore Currency Wobble
summary: Beijing got a reality check on its plans to internationalize the yuan, when the currency was hit by an unprecedented selloff in Hong Kong last week.

headline: Spain on Track to Meet Deficit Target
summary: Spain's budget gap widened to 2.8% of gross domestic product in the first eight months of the year from 2.1% in the first seven months, but the country is still on track to meet its target for this year.

headline: Turkish Ship Explores Off Southern Cyprus
summary: A Turkish oil and gas research ship is exploring off southern Cyprus in an area near the exploration rig operated by Noble Energy,  in a further escalation of a conflict over drilling rights.

headline: U.K. Retail Sales Weaken
summary: U.K. retail sales were lower in September from a year earlier and retailers expect sales to weaken further next month, the latest sign that the economy is slowing.

headline: BP Proposes Route for Azerbaijan Gas
summary: BP has proposed a fourth route for a pipeline to feed Europe with Caspian natural gas, as the fight among competing pipeline projects heats up ahead of an Oct. 1 deadline.

headline: Russian Central Bank Defends Ruble, Won't Change Forex Policy
summary: None

headline: Korean Minister Resigns Over Blackouts
summary: South Korea's energy minister stepped down to take responsibility for recent massive power blackouts that caused chaos across the country.

headline: BAE Cuts Nearly 3,000 Jobs
summary: U.K. defense company BAE Systems announced plans to cut almost 3,000 jobs in the U.K., in a bid to cut costs as production slows on major jet-fighter programs in the U.S. and Europe.

headline: Typhoon Nesat Hits the Philippines
summary: More than 100,000 people were ordered to flee their homes as a large typhoon slammed the Philippine archipelago. Schools have been closed and flights grounded.

headline: EasyJet Should Call Stelios's Bluff
summary: Rising profits and a bonus dividend should make any investor happy, particularly in the ever turbulent European airline industry. So what's up with easyJet-founder Stelios Haji-Ioannou?

headline: Banks Seek Safety at ECB
summary: Euro-zone banks' overnight deposits with the European Central Bank rose to the highest amount since the Sept. 12 peak for this year.

headline: Deloitte Sued Over Taylor Bean Collapse
summary: The trustee overseeing the bankruptcy of Taylor Bean & Whitaker Mortgage filed a lawsuit against Deloitte & Touche, saying the firm's "grossly negligent audits" contributed to the mortgage lender's collapse.

headline: Strong Demand at Japanese Bond Auction
summary: Investors showed fairly strong interest in a sale of two-year Japanese government bonds, amid speculation that the Bank of Japan may announce fresh policy moves next week.

headline: Rashtriya Ispat IPO Could Take Six Months
summary: The Indian government's plan for an initial public offering of state-run steelmaker Rashtriya Ispat Nigam could take at least six more months, Steel Secretary Pradeep Kumar Misra said.

headline: Reliance Group Firms in Stake Sale Talks
summary: Indian billionaire Anil Ambani's Reliance Group is looking to sell stakes in its telecommunications, asset management and general insurance businesses, as it seeks funds to pare debt which has been weighing on its performance.

headline: Fortis Delays Singapore IPO
summary: Fortis Healthcare (India) has delayed a planned $400 million Singapore listing of a unit until the first quarter of next year, two people familiar with the situation said, as it grapples with volatile stock markets and procedural delays to the ambitious deal.

headline: Indian Shares End Sharply Higher
summary: Indian shares rose sharply after four sessions of consecutive losses, as investors across Asia and Europe piled into recently battered stocks.

headline: Mongolia Reported to Seek Mining Changes
summary: The Canadian owner of the massive Oyu Tolgoi mining project in Mongolia said an existing investment agreement stands amid reports the Mongolian government is seeking changes.

headline: Indian Oil Considering Second East Coast Gas Terminal
summary: State-run refiner Indian Oil Corp. is considering building a second terminal to import liquefied natural gas on the country's eastern coast as part of its upcoming Paradip refinery complex.

headline: Asia Markets Follow Wall Street Rebound
summary: Asian stocks gained sharply after reports of new plans under consideration to support debt-strapped European countries fueled hope that a solution to the region's woes could be in sight. South Korea's Kospi surged 5%.

headline: Maruti Resumes SX4 Production at Manesar
summary: Maruti Suzuki India resumed manufacturing the SX4 sedan at its factory at Manesar, in the northern state of Haryana even as it added 120 technicians at the facility, increasing the total workforce to 1,500.

headline: India's Top 10 Tourist Destinations
summary: On World Tourism Day, a look at the top 10 most popular destinations for domestic tourists in India. In pictures.

headline: Champions League Twenty20
summary: Mumbai Indians beat Trinidad and Tobago by one wicket on Monday, with Yuzvendra Chahal scoring the winning runs off the final ball. Some snapshots.

headline: Turkish Leader's Guards Scuffle at U.N.
summary: Several brawls broke out between U.N. security staff and bodyguards protecting Turkey's Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan inside the UN's General Assembly hall on Friday, U.N. officials confirmed Monday.

headline: Dabur India to Invest $15 Million in Sri Lanka
summary: Dabur India said it will set up a new export-oriented manufacturing plant in Sri Lanka with an initial investment of $15 million.

headline: India Gold, Silver Futures Hit Initial Upper Limits
summary: India's gold and silver futures on the Multi Commodity Exchange hit their initial upper limits, tracking a firm overseas market and as fresh buying emerged at lower levels following a sharp fall in the past few days.

headline: Funds Buy Australian Toll Road Firm for $2.2 Billion
summary: Funds managed by private Australian infrastructure investor CP2 will take control of one of Melbourne's biggest toll roads after ConnectEast Group shareholders approved its $2.16 billion bid for the company.

headline: Deals India: Morning News Roundup
summary: News roundup from Indian newspapers, news wires and Web sites on Tuesday, September 27, 2011. Deals India has not verified the stories from other media organizations and does not vouch for their accuracy.

headline: GAIL India to Buy Stakes in LNG Projects in Australia
summary: GAIL India is in separate talks with U.S.-based Chevron and Algeria's state-run Sonatrach to acquire stakes in their liquefied natural gas projects in Australia and Algeria, the Economic Times newspaper reported.

headline: JSW May Shut Main India Plant
summary: JSW Steel may have to shut its 10 million metric tons a year steel plant in the southern Indian town of Vijaynagar as it continues to grapple with an iron-ore shortage, the company's vice chairman Sajjan Jindal said.

headline: Reliance Capital in Talks With Nippon to Sell Stake
summary: India's Reliance Capital is planning to sell stakes in its asset management and general insurance businesses, and may apply to the central bank for a banking license to tap high growth opportunities in the financial sector, its chairman said.

headline: Indian Oil to Have 26% Share in JV With Nuclear Power
summary: Indian Oil will invest $195 million for a 26% stake in a joint venture with Nuclear Power Corp. of India, the chairman of the state-run refiner and fuel retailer said.

headline: ReNew Wind Power Gets $201 Million Goldman Investment
summary: ReNew Wind Power, a company set up by former Suzlon Energy Chief Operating Officer Sumant Sinha, said Goldman Sachs Group will invest up to $201 million in the wind power producer.

headline: China's Ansteel to Build India Steel Plant
summary: Anshan Iron & Steel Group, China's third-largest steelmaker by output, will likely establish a steel processing plant in India to take advantage of the positive outlook for steel demand there, a senior company executive said.

headline: German Consumers Defy Gloom
summary: German consumers appear untroubled by the sovereign-debt crisis and its possible impact on the real economy, due to the strength of the labor market, market-research group GfK said.

headline: India in Pictures
summary: Floods in Orissa, a ragpicker on a beach, celebrations for the Prime Minister's birthday and more.

headline: What's News
summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: Error of Margin in Precious Metal Theories
summary: Gold and silver attract conspiracy theories like JFK and Roswell. The theory-du-jour concerns exchanges supposedly driving down prices by raising the amount of margin investors must post to open and maintain futures positions.

headline: Aspiring D-Leaguer? Apply Within
summary: Basketball players convened at the Baruch College gym Monday with a common ambition: to become the next star of the Erie BayHawks. Among them were a professional poker player and a tax attorney.

headline: Ricardo Backed Specialization for Nations
summary: British economist David Ricardo changed how people think about trade when he came up with the theory of comparative advantage: Countries do best, he said, by concentrating on their strengths, and then trading with others for everything else.

headline: Buffalo's Secret: A Stampede
summary: A key to the Buffalo Bills' surprising 3-0 start is bunching their receivers at the line of scrimmage: a strategy taken from the rival New England Patriots.

headline: Caterpillar Sees China Gains Continuing
summary: Caterpillar remains confident about its prospects in China over the next few years despite a recent slowing of the Chinese economy as authorities there fight inflation.

headline: MTA Puts More on the Block
summary: As part of a months-long review of its real estate, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority plans to put nine more properties on the block, including the mostly empty building in Downtown Brooklyn that has long angered the borough's politicians.

headline: Jackson Doctor Set for Trial
summary: The doctor accused of manslaughter in the 2009 death of Michael Jackson is set to stand trial Tuesday, a proceeding that will draw coverage by media outlets around the world.

headline: Will Buffett's Floor Also Be a Ceiling?
summary: From Harley-Davidson to Bank of America, Warren Buffett's investments are known for lighting a fire under weak stocks. The latest in need of help: his own company.

headline: Obama Goes on the Attack Early
summary: President Barack Obama, setting aside plans to stay out of the 2012 campaign until his GOP opponent emerges, has sharpened his line of attack against Republicans during a West Coast swing and injected himself into the GOP presidential-nomination fight.

headline: Japan, Philippines Seek Tighter Ties
summary: Military and security ties will be a topic when Philippine President Benigno Aquino III meets Tuesday in Tokyo with Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda, as both countries face intensifying territorial disputes with China.

headline: Brooke Jackman's Books
summary: The night before the attacks of 9/11, Brooke Jackman completed her application for graduate school in social work. When the first plane hit the north tower, Brooke was at her job on the 104th floor. After her death, her family decided to affirm her memory by promoting her passion for books.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of Sept. 27, 2011

headline: United Feels Merger Pains
summary: Merged airline United Continental faces government, labor and technology challenges. The Air Line Pilots Association sued the company in federal court over "revised operating procedures."

headline: Chevron, Partners Approve $29 Billion LNG Project
summary: Chevron and partners placed a $29 billion bet on Asian demand for clean-burning fuels by approving construction of the Wheatstone gas-export project in Australia, overlooking worries about the global economy and competitive new energy sources.

headline: Minimalist Ibiza Villa
summary: This ultra-modern, six-bedroom home in Cap Martinet sits on a hillside overlooking Ibiza's medieval walled city and harbor.

headline: New Views Of Hormone Therapy in Menopause
summary: The 25 million American women turning 50 in the next decade face a decision: Hormone replacement therapy, or not? Some experts are concluding that hormone therapy may still be a good option for healthy women in their 50s.

headline: 'Venus' Pulls Dancy Into a Broadway Orbit
summary: The Hugh Dancy chats about his new role in 'Venus in Fur.'

headline: Food Marketer Struck Gold With Doritos
summary: Arch West, who died Sept. 20 at age 97, created Doritos, the best-selling tortilla chips in the U.S. and the product that introduced Americans to a flavor called Nacho cheese.

headline: Mr. Buffett's Tax Secrets
summary: The least he can do is show Americans why he pays so little.

headline: Eni Restarts Libya Production
summary: Italy's Eni became the second Western energy company to restart oil production in Libya, reinforcing hopes of a swift recovery for the country's war-battered oil sector.

headline: 10-Year Deal Links Ailey, City Center
summary: The dance troupe will become City Center's principal dance company and continue to perform its five-week winter season there for the next 10 years.

headline: Russia Ousts Finance Chief
summary: In a rare public dustup among Kremlin officials, Russia's president forced out the country's finance minister, dressing him down before state-run television for taking a stance against his policies.

headline: Apple Presses Samsung Tablet Ban
summary: A legal dispute between Apple and Samsung in Australia intensified with an attorney representing Apple alleging Samsung's product infringes on touch-screen technology-related patents.

headline: Extortion Charges Hit Labor Coalition
summary: The price of "security" at some construction sites was $1,000 a month.  "Labor peace" was more expensive: $400 a week. Even "good will" was for sale, going for $100 a week.

headline: Tokyo Moves Closer to Buying a New Generation of Jet Fighters
summary: Japan moved a step closer to buying a new generation of jet fighters after it accepted bids by three of the world's biggest defense contractors for what is expected to be a multibillion dollar deal.

headline: Balanced Funds Tilt Toward Stocks as Investors Scale Back
summary: While individual investors have been fleeing the stock market for months, some fund managers have been pushing them right back in. Among asset-allocation fund managers, the trend has been stocks, stocks and more stocks.

headline: One 'Slugger' Rivera Is Reluctant to Face
summary: Boston Red Sox shortstop Marco Scutaro joined one of baseball's most exclusive clubs Sunday: players Mariano Rivera is too scared to face. Plus, the NHL's worst-kept secret was officially revealed on Monday.

headline: What's News: World-Wide
summary: What's News: World-Wide Top Stories for Sept. 27, 2011

headline: Hidden Flaw in P&G's Diamond Deal
summary: Procter & Gamble's plan to combine its Pringles unit with Diamond Foods should come with a warning label: Old business problems won't disappear.

headline: Netflix, Amazon Add to Movies
summary: Netflix reached a deal to stream DreamWorks movies and Amazon.com reached a deal for Fox TV shows and movies.

headline: Paychex to Offer Jobs Pulse Check
summary: Payroll-services firm Paychex is due out with fiscal first-quarter results Tuesday that—for better or worse—will offer some clarity on recent labor-market conditions.

headline: Presidential Malpractice
summary: Crazy as he was, Garfield's assassin was right to insist that the doctor who gravely mistreated the president was responsible for his death. Fergus Bordewich reviews.

headline: Ohio Shale Sparks Deals
summary: One of the latest hot spots for deal making is in eastern Ohio, where energy companies are staking claims in what is being touted as North America's next big energy field, the Utica Shale.

headline: Deal Pinch for French Banks
summary: Plans by BNP Paribas and Société Générale to sell assets as a way of shoring up capital and regaining investor confidence could struggle as the deteriorating global economy makes it harder to spin off businesses at a decent price.

headline: FDA Flags Concern on Birth-Control Pill
summary: The FDA said it "remains concerned" a certain type of birth-control pill that contains drospirenone could raise the risk of blood clots beyond that of other pills.

headline: Drug Known as 'Milk of Amnesia'
summary: Propofol, the drug blamed in Michael Jackson's death, is popular among anesthesiologists because it acts quickly and, when used properly, has few aftereffects.

headline: Treasury Prices Slide as Havens Lose Allure
summary: Investors fled their safe-haven hideouts Monday, sending Treasury prices lower because of optimism that global policy makers are homing in on a plan to resolve the euro zone's sovereign-debt crisis.

headline: Blinken Makes Some Good Points but Doesn't Convince
summary: Regarding Antony J. Blinken's Sept. 20 letter on Obama-Israeli relations:A  wink to his profound comment that nations don't always see eye to eye; the blink is to the administration's making Israeli legitimacy the issue (rather than the legitimacy of the Palestinian state).

headline: L.A. Museum Holds 'Intimate' Gala for 600
summary: Even if 600 guests ventured to the Hammer Museum over the weekend for its ninth annual "Gala in the Garden," the evening still managed to remain kind of intimate.

headline: ECB Cuts Purchases of Bonds
summary: The ECB dramatically scaled back its purchases of government bonds last week despite strains in financial markets, putting renewed pressure on governments to step up efforts to stem the debt crisis.

headline: Europe's Banks Face New Squeeze
summary: An extraordinary dry spell in the market for long-term European bank funding is amplifying pressure on policy makers to devise a solution to the Continent's banking crisis.

headline: Medicare Records Case Moves Forward in Court
summary: A federal judge in Florida has ruled that a case aimed at overturning a 32-year-old injunction that bars the public from seeing the Medicare billing records of individual doctors can proceed.

headline: A Better Beddy-Bye
summary: Cranky Consumer asks consultants to help a 3-year-old sleep through the night.

headline: Texas's Immigration Choices
summary: Rick Perry's pragmatism draws fire from his presidential rivals.

headline: Afghan Insider Kills American CIA Worker
summary: An Afghan employee killed one American and wounded another at CIA offices in Kabul, an attack that called attention to U.S. security concerns about reliance on local partners.

headline: Museum Moves Beyond Its Walls
summary: The Children's Museum of Manhattan will open a permanent exhibition in an East Harlem public housing project in what officials hope can become a national model.

headline: Romney's Right, We Need a China Policy Fairer to the U.S.
summary: Your editorial "Romney's China Blunder" (Sept. 17) asks presidential candidates to protect the national interest. Confronting China's mercantilist trade agenda is clearly within the national interest, and is exactly the policy which Mitt Romney has proposed.

headline: The Sweet Smell of Easier Weight Loss?
summary: Scented products can trigger your body to think it's full, aiding weight loss, say companies who sell the products. Nutritionists and doctors who specialize in weight loss say the research conducted so far isn't convincing.

headline: Spain's Famous Bull May Be on Last Legs
summary: Ratón—one of thousands of bulls that chase bull runners—is whipping up a fervor like few have seen in years. The bull's popularity stands out at a time when Spain's other major bull event, bullfighting, is under siege.

headline: New Homes Again Log Slow Sales
summary: New-home sales fell for the fourth-straight month in August to the lowest level in a half year as the bursting of the housing bubble continued to weigh on the U.S. economic recovery.

headline: 100 Reasons Robertson Is the Closer in Waiting
summary: With his next K, the Yankees setup man will be the first Yankee reliever to strike out 100 since Mariano Rivera in 1996.

headline: John Steele Gordon: A Short History of the Income Tax
summary: One original sin was the separation of the corporate and personal tax, giving lawyers, accountants and the wealthy a chance to game the system.

headline: Animal Terrorism Law Sets Unusual Standard for Crime
summary: Under a 2006 law, activists can face prison time if the target of an animal-rights protest feels threatened, regardless of the protesters' intentions.

headline: SEC Warns Over S&P Mortgage Rating
summary: The SEC told Standard & Poor's that it could face enforcement action over a mortgage-backed bond, in the first such warning issued to a credit-rating firm in relation to the financial crisis.

headline: The Best Way to Select Judges
summary: Regarding the Letters of Sept. 21 responding to your editorial "Missouri Compromised" (Sept. 15): The best method is by an election held for the attorneys who will practice in front of that judge.

headline: Blue-State Math Is Boon to Obama, Target for GOP
summary: Amid those dark political clouds overhead now, Obama still can console himself with this silver lining: The electoral map remains stacked in favor of him and his Democrats.

headline: Sadanand Dhume: Is Pakistan Too Big to Fail?
summary: The country's generals behave with impunity because they believe the United States will always blink first.

headline: Nokia's Troubles Hit Suppliers
summary: Market struggles at Nokia have had ripple effects among major suppliers that could reshape the supply chain for smartphones.

headline: Jets Lose Tight End Cumberland for Year
summary: Plus, Rex Ryan fires back at Joe Namath's criticism of the Jets, and the Mets block the Yankees from planting their Triple-A team in Newark for a year.

headline: A Fannie Mae for Europe's Bonds?
summary: The latest idea to avoid facing Greek facts.

headline: Tallying the Toll of U.S.-China Trade
summary: Many Americans believe low-priced Chinese imports kill U.S. factory jobs. Most economists say the benefits of the trade far outweigh its costs. New research suggests the damage to the U.S. has been deeper than supposed.

headline: Making Europe Safer
summary: A cleverly designed bond instrument can ensure the euro zone's survival without a fiscal union.

headline: India Wary on Drug Deals
summary: A government committee in India is expected to submit a report this week recommending that the country scrutinize pharmaceutical mergers and perhaps make it harder for foreign investors to acquire drug makers.

headline: Defense Strikes at Bloomberg
summary: Defense attorneys for a political operative charged with stealing $1.1 million from Mayor Bloomberg tried to turn the trial on its head Monday, accusing the mayor of "deception," "arrogance" and a drive to win his 2009 re-election campaign "at all costs."

headline: On the Road With the Festival Crew
summary: With the benefit of new technology, filmmakers can act as their own distributors.

headline: Kodak Plunges Over New Cash Worries
summary: Kodak raised fresh concerns about its ability to pull off a long-running turnaround by borrowing more money at a time when it had told investors it would be generating cash.

headline: Tumblr Valued at $800 Million
summary: Tumblr has scant revenue and a nascent business model, but the fast-growing blogging service said it raised $85 million in venture capital. The investment values the company at $800 million.
